author: By Roxanne Fequiere
title: Recapture The Thrill of Being on Wheels
description: After a year spent largely indoors, adults are regaining a sense of balance on roller skates, bikes and skateboards.
content: First came the walks — and then, seemingly all at once, the wheels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: People across the U.S. face a maze of questions about whether to mask.
description: CHICAGO — The sudden loosening of federal health guidance on masks left Americans with options — and lots of questions. Would they leave the mask behind for a jog? What about the coffee shop? What about the neighbor’s house? The office?
content: CHICAGO — The sudden loosening of federal health guidance on masks left Americans with options — and lots of questions. Would they leave the mask behind for a jog? What about the coffee shop? What about the neighbor’s house? The office?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Unemployment Pay May Again Require a Job Search. Is It Too Soon?
description: The requirement, eased because of the pandemic, is being reimposed. Some say it presents an undue hardship.
content: A tenet of the American unemployment system has been that anyone collecting benefits, in good times and bad, must look for work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Try a new recipe sometime soon, whether it’s for chile-roasted chicken with honey, lemon and feta, or spring-vegetable japchae.
content: Good morning. Fifty years ago today the front page of The Times brought news from Cairo and Vietnam, and from President Nixon’s compound on Key Biscayne, Fla. There were reports from Chicago and London, from Dublin and from Fifth Avenue in New York, where on Saturday 10,000 members of the nation’s military had marched in the 22nd Armed Forces Day Parade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 17, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel, Mitch Smith and Christina Morales
title: The C.D.C. director offers a stark reassurance: Only unvaccinated people are at risk by unmasking.
description: In a round of Sunday morning news, Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky sought to quell the public confusion over her agency’s new masking guidance.
content: The head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, facing blowback over the agency’s new liberalized mask guidelines, offered a stark reassurance on Sunday: Only unvaccinated people are at risk if they take off their masks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Jack Terricloth, Punk Rocker With a Cabaret Air, Dies at 50
description: As the devilishly smarmy vocalist and ringleader of the World/Inferno Friendship Society, he melded punk defiance with decadent theatricality.
content: To old friends who met him backstage, he was Pete Ventantonio, a punk rocker from Bridgewater, N.J. On his records, he sometimes preferred whimsical credits like Marcello DiTerriclothia or Favorite Singer Who Goes With Everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rothfeld
title: How Eric Adams, Mayoral Candidate, Mixed Money and Political Ambition
description: Mr. Adams, the Brooklyn borough president, has called money the “enemy of politics.” But his fund-raising has repeatedly pushed the boundaries of campaign-finance and ethics laws.
content: Eric Adams, the Brooklyn borough president, had begun making the rounds for a nascent mayoral campaign when he arrived at a small gathering in spring 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: When Fighting Erupts Between Israel and Hamas, the Question of War Crimes Follows
description: Civilian deaths on both sides raise urgent questions about which military actions are legal, what war crimes are being committed and who, if anyone, will be held to account.
content: The Israeli missile that slammed into a Palestinian apartment exacted a shocking toll: eight children and two women, killed as they celebrated a major Muslim holiday, in one of the deadliest episodes of the war between Israel and Palestinian militants that has raged for nearly a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sy Montgomery
title: That Most Enchanting Bird in the World
description: In “Why Peacocks?” Sean Flynn adopts three of these amazing animals and learns to see their personality and intelligence and foibles and charms.
content: WHY PEACOCKS?An Unlikely Search for Meaning in the World’s Most Magnificent BirdBy Sean Flynn
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kieran Press-Reynolds
title: How Roblox Sparked a Chaotic Music Scene
description: Players can customize their own worlds on the platform. Many illegally upload songs — called “bypassing audio” — and some make intense tracks in a new genre, robloxcore.
content: Artists, label heads and industry schemers know that success in pop music today requires racking up plays on TikTok and streaming services. But there’s another, unlikely platform that’s picking up steam: Roblox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Under $500,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: A Ransom for Fuel
description: Hackers extorted nearly $5 million after disrupting a major U.S. pipeline.
content: Good morning and happy Sunday. Here’s what you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Brought the Old Clunker Out to the Stoop So That Someone Could Take It’
description: Getting rid of a television, a solitary ride on the Manhattan Bridge and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier Blas and Jack Farchy
title: Drag Commodity Traders Out of the Shadows
description: We need strong laws and clear regulations to shed light on this megapowerful sector of the global economy.
content: In the final days of Donald Trump’s presidency, all eyes in Washington were on the unprecedented second impeachment of a sitting president following the riots on Capitol Hill. No one noticed when, on Jan. 15, the Treasury quietly eased sanctions on a man it had previously described as profiting from “corruption and misconduct.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee and John Koblin
title: AT&T-Discovery Deal Would Create a Media Juggernaut
description: A merger could be announced as soon as Monday, in a deal that would offload the media business that AT&T fought to buy.
content: Less than three years after AT&T spent over $85 billion and millions more fending off a government challenge to buy Time Warner, one of the biggest prizes in media, the phone company has decided on a completely different strategy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iyad Abuheweila and Patrick Kingsley
title: Grief Mounts as Efforts to Ease Israel-Hamas Fight Falter
description: The diplomatic wrangling came as at least 42 Palestinians were killed early Sunday in an airstrike in Gaza City, the deadliest episode in the recent bloodshed.
content: GAZA CITY — Diplomats and international leaders were unable Sunday to mediate a cease-fire in the latest conflict between Israel and Hamas, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel vowed to continue the fight and the United Nations Security Council failed to agree on a joint response to the worsening bloodshed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Whipple
title: The Many Blunders of the Secret Service — and the Dangers They Pose to U.S. Presidents
description: Carol Leonnig’s “Zero Fail” is a thoroughly researched and devastating indictment of the United States Secret Service.
content: ZERO FAIL
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Marie Fazio
title: Bucknell Investigating ‘Horrific’ Harassment of L.G.B.T.Q. Students
description: The university said a group of men tried to enter a house for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender students last week. Residents said they were terrified and traumatized by the episode.
content: Officials at Bucknell University have ordered an investigation into what they described as a “horrific” episode of harassment targeting residents at a house for L.G.B.T.Q. students on its campus in Lewisburg, Pa., last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: In pictures: Fire and thunder fill the night sky as Israel’s Iron Dome is tested.
description: The system that protects Israeli cities has had to intercept a barrage of rockets over the past week.
content: As the worst violence in years rages between the Israeli military and Hamas, each night the sky is lit up by a barrage of missiles and the projectiles designed to counter them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar and Jeffrey Gettleman
title: A Desperate India Falls Prey to Covid Scammers
description: As the health care system fails, clandestine markets have emerged for drugs, oxygen, hospital beds and funeral services. Fake goods may be putting lives at risk.
content: NEW DELHI — Within the world’s worst coronavirus outbreak, few treasures are more coveted than an empty oxygen canister. India’s hospitals desperately need the metal cylinders to store and transport the lifesaving gas as patients across the country gasp for breath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Scenes From America’s Reopening
description: With safety restrictions easing, Americans from Maine to Montana are returning to concert halls, worship services and soapbox derbies in all 50 states.
content: With climbing vaccinations and dwindling virus cases, Americans from Honolulu to Sumter, S.C., have begun to return to the things they did before — the nights out, religious services and annual traditions that made life richer. But after a year of isolation, it has all been a bit uncertain, both familiar and not quite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Vanessa Bryant Delivers Emotional Hall of Fame Speech for Kobe
description: Kobe Bryant, the former Los Angeles Lakers star who was killed in a helicopter crash last year, was posthumously inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame on Saturday.
content: Vanessa Bryant, the wife of the late Kobe Bryant, accepted induction into the Basketball Hall of Fame on her husband’s behalf on Saturday, saying that his absence made writing a speech all the more challenging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Australia’s first repatriation flight from India returns half empty.
description: The Australian government says 70 people were barred from boarding the plane after they or someone close to them tested positive for Covid.
content: Days after ending its divisive ban on allowing citizens to return from India, Australia carried out its first repatriation flight from that country, with the plane departing from New Delhi and arriving in Darwin, in Australia’s Northern Territory, on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Deaths surpass 200 in Israel-Gaza crisis.
content: At least 33 people died in Gaza on Sunday after Israel’s single deadliest airstrike in a weeklong bombing campaign that has killed at least 192 people — most of them civilians, including 58 children — according to Palestinian officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabby Sobelman
title: Bleachers collapsed inside a crowded synagogue, injuring more than 100.
description: More than 100 worshipers were injured and two were killed on Sunday evening, when a seating structure collapsed inside a crowded, unfinished synagogue near Jerusalem that officials said had not been deemed safe for use.
content: More than 100 worshipers were injured and two were killed on Sunday evening, when a seating structure collapsed inside a crowded, unfinished synagogue near Jerusalem that officials said had not been deemed safe for use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Learn About Gems and Read Aloud With a Drag Queen
description: This week, discover the cultural and societal impact of sneakers, practice your math skills or explore what a net zero climate might look like.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christy Harmon
title: Use Yesterday’s News to Dress Up Your Plants
description: Revisit your childhood gum-wrapper-folding skills to add a crowning touch to a flowerpot.
content: If you were a school-age kid in the 1980s, there’s a good chance you spent countless hours in the back of class perfecting chains of gum wrappers that once graced all of the Fruit Stripes (and other brands) you had chewed your way through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: In New Vaccination Push, Biden Leans on His ‘Community Corps’
description: Frantic efforts to vaccinate people in an underserved area of Philadelphia underscore a difficult new stage of the nation’s vaccination campaign, as door-to-door efforts become the norm.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Only a trickle of people had visited her community vaccination site seeking a first coronavirus shot last Monday when Dr. Ala Stanford, a local pediatric surgeon, seized on an unexpected opening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: On the Scrappy Fringes of French Politics, Marine Le Pen Tries to Rebrand
description: Marine Le Pen, the far-right leader and main challenger to President Emmanuel Macron in next year’s election, wants to persuade voters that she and her party can govern France.
content: LA TRINITÉ-SUR-MER, France — It was the setting for a straightforward origin story, or so it seemed. Marine Le Pen, the far-right leader aiming to be France’s next president, came to launch her latest campaign in the seaside resort where her firebrand father once announced his own bid for the presidency from the family home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Refresh With a Mint Drink
description: Mint is a wonderful flavor to enrich warm-weather coolers.
content: Mint has a great deal to say. This persistent perennial contributes refreshing coolness to food and drink, often with a bittersweet edge and sometimes spiked with notes of pepper. It’s not subtle like some herbs, and makes its presence known in everything from cocktails to candy, regardless of whether the context is savory or sweet. Frankly, it’s hard to overdo its use. Mint is also easy to grow in a window box or garden, allowing for leaves to always be on hand, especially come spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Basketball Hall of Fame to Enshrine 16 More
description: The next class will include Chris Bosh, Paul Pierce, Ben Wallace, Chris Webber, Toni Kukoc, Bill Russell (as a coach this time), Yolanda Griffith, Lauren Jackson and Jay Wright.
content: SPRINGFIELD, Mass. — Jay Wright used to sell tickets to games in the United States Football League. Ben Wallace was passed over by every N.B.A. team, some of them twice. Yolanda Griffith got a job repossessing cars so she could take care of herself and her infant daughter while playing community college basketball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ionova
title: Why Is Covid Killing So Many Young Children in Brazil? Doctors Are Baffled
description: Experts believe Brazil’s overloaded hospital system and uneven access to health care are among the reasons babies and small children are succumbing to the virus at a high rate.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Fretting over a fever in her toddler that wouldn’t break, the mother took the young girl, Letícia, to a hospital. Doctors had worrisome news: It was Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

title: From The Sunday Read Archive: ‘Weird Al Yankovic’s Weirdly Enduring Appeal’
description: National economies collapse; species go extinct; coronavirus upends our world. But — through it all — Weird Al keeps rocking.
content: On this episode of The Sunday Read, staff writer Sam Anderson claims Weird Al Yankovic is not just a parody singer — he’s “a full-on rock star, a legitimate performance monster and a spiritual technician doing important work down in the engine room of the American soul.” In these absurd times, Sam reaches into his childhood to explain the enduring appeal of an absurd artist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Swift and Shauntel Lowe
title: The Liberty Get Another Shot at a Fresh Start
description: Fans of the Liberty finally got a proper introduction to their team’s new look on Friday in Brooklyn, even as reminders of the past year of turmoil remain.
content: They weren’t supposed to meet this way, the new-look Liberty and their fans in sea foam green. The chants for Sabrina Ionescu, the 2020 No. 1 overall pick, were supposed to have echoed in Barclays Center last spring. She was supposed to rain down 3-pointers, and the Liberty were, fans believed, going to rack up wins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Marcus Payadue
title: Israel, Masks, Triple Crown: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Netanyahu says there is no clear end in sight, and airstrikes begin again.
description: Speaking on CBS’ Face The Nation on Sunday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said there was no clear end in sight to the violence between Israel and Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.
content: Speaking on CBS’ Face The Nation on Sunday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said there was no clear end in sight to the violence between Israel and Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: For Jrue Holiday, It’s a Good Game When His Wife Says So
description: The pressure is on as the Bucks head to the N.B.A. playoffs, but Holiday has somebody at home who understands competition: his wife, Lauren, who faced high expectations on the U.S. national soccer team.
content: It was not until May, which the Bucks began with back-to-back victories over the Nets, that Milwaukee loudly announced it was still an N.B.A. championship contender. Jrue Holiday scored 14 points in the first quarter of the second win, and in a contented home locker room, one of the league’s foremost defensive players let his guard down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Vivian Yee and Shashank Bengali
title: Israel’s attack on a press building in Gaza draws condemnations.
description: Media groups demand explanations after Israeli forces destroyed the high-rise that housed the offices of The Associated Press and other news outlets.
content: The prominent 12-story building in Gaza City that was destroyed in an Israeli airstrike on Saturday not only housed the offices of media organizations including The Associated Press and Al Jazeera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter and Matthew Goldstein
title: Long Before Divorce, Bill Gates Had Reputation for Questionable Behavior
description: Melinda French Gates voiced concerns about her husband’s relationship with Jeffrey Epstein and a harassment claim against his money manager. He also had an affair with an employee.
content: By the time Melinda French Gates decided to end her 27-year marriage, her husband was known globally as a software pioneer, a billionaire and a leading philanthropist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: The assault on Gaza halts Covid shots and could spread the virus, U.N. officials warn.
description: The officials see the possibility of the virus spreading among unvaccinated Gazans cramming into shelters during Israeli airstrikes.
content: Israel’s airstrikes and shelling of Gaza have stopped all Covid-19 vaccinations and testing in the Palestinian enclave and raise the risk of super-spreading as civilians cram into shelters for safety, United Nations officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Maya Wiley Lands Major Endorsement From Rep. Hakeem Jeffries
description: Mr. Jeffries, New York’s top House Democrat, said he intended to engage in significant efforts on Ms. Wiley’s behalf, including making campaign appearances with her.
content: Representative Hakeem Jeffries of New York, the state’s highest-ranking House Democrat, is throwing his support to Maya D. Wiley in the race for mayor of New York City, a significant endorsement at a critical juncture in the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Tel Aviv, Israel’s Bustling Financial Hub, Shaken as Rockets Rain Down
description: The largely liberal, secular beachside city has a reputation for being a hedonistic bubble. But during the past week, Tel Aviv has been targeted by at least 160 rockets.
content: TEL AVIV — Tel Aviv’s city hall launched a playful social media campaign this month declaring itself a vaccinated city eager to welcome back international travelers on their first post-coronavirus trips abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellie Carter Jackson
title: Hollywood Has Finally Deemed Black Women Worthy of Feel-Good TV
description: The depiction of empowered, loving Black women in “Run the World” should not feel radical, but it is.
content: Do you remember that scene in “Sex and the City” when Carrie gets dumped by her boyfriend via Post-it note? “I’m sorry,” it reads. “I can’t. Don’t hate me.” That’s what I think of when my friends ask if I’ve seen the latest TV show populated almost entirely by white people: I’m sorry. I can’t. Don’t hate me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: In a Dark Year on Campus, Some Surprising Glimmers of Light
description: College in a pandemic was not the experience that most students had in mind. But at year’s end, some see positive experiences and insights that came out of it.
content: It was the year of college without the college experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Long Tail of Covid-19
description: Many are ready for the country to reach a pre-Covid-19 normal, but  others may never reach that point.
content: When the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention made an abrupt change to its guidance on Thursday, stating that fully vaccinated people could stop wearing masks in most settings, it was welcomed, if not whiplash-inducing, news.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 16, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Sunday, May 16, 2021.
content: The Scene City article last Sunday misspelled the name of a restaurant frequented by the curator Thelma Golden. It is Vinatería, not Vinoteria. The article also misspelled the given name of an artist whose work is on exhibit at the Whitney. He is Dawoud Bey, not Dauwood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: In Washington, hundreds take part in pro-Palestinian protests.
description: News of the march to the U.S. Capitol spread largely through social media and word of mouth, including during Friday prayers at local mosques.
content: WASHINGTON — Hours after Israel launched an airstrike on a Gaza media tower, hundreds of protesters marched Saturday afternoon from the Washington Monument to the U.S. Capitol in protest of Israel’s treatment of the Palestinian people and what they said was an inadequate response from the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: 500 Homes Ordered Evacuated in Palisades Fire in California
description: The fire burned through 750 acres in the Topanga Canyon area in Los Angeles County and was at zero percent containment on Saturday night, fire officials said.
content: A brush fire in California, which sent smoky plumes into the sky above Los Angeles County as it continued to burn on Sunday, has forced the evacuation of more than 500 homes, the Los Angeles County Fire Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Williams and Phil Hatcher-Moore
title: A Curious Golfer, a Lawn Mower and a Thousand Hours in Lockdown
description: During the coronavirus pandemic, Chris Powell became obsessed with his Welsh town’s golf course, long lost to time and the land. Then he rebuilt it, to play for a single day.
content: On Friday evening, Chris Powell and 23 locals stood in a field roughly a mile from his home in the rolling hills of Rhayader in Mid Wales. All around the group, familiar features dotted the landscape — from a winding series of public footpaths to gorse bushes, patches of bracken and a centuries-old stone cottage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: A Scratched Hint of Ancient Ties Stirs National Furies in Europe
description: Czech archaeologists say marks found on a cattle bone are sixth-century Germanic runes, in a Slavic settlement. The find has provoked an academic and nationalist brawl.
content: LANY, Czech Republic — In a region long fought over by rival ethnic and linguistic groups, archaeologists in the Czech Republic have discovered something unusual in these turbulent parts: evidence that peoples locked in hostility for much of the modern era got along in centuries past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: From India, Brazil and Beyond: Pandemic Refugees at the Border
description: Fleeing virus-devastated economies, migrants are traveling long distances to reach the United States and then walking through gaps in the border wall. The Arizona desert has become a favorite crossing point.
content: YUMA, Ariz. — Standing by the hulking border wall, a U.S. Border Patrol agent watched as a car dropped off passengers at the edge of a road on the Mexican side. “Oh, no,” he muttered. “Here come some more.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Israel carried out its deadliest strike yet, as the fighting raged on.
description: The violence showed no sign of abating on Sunday, as Israel made the single deadliest airstrike yet on Gaza in the weeklong bombing campaign, and the number of rockets fired at Israel from Gaza topped 3,000.
content: The violence showed no sign of abating on Sunday, as Israel made the single deadliest airstrike yet on Gaza in the weeklong bombing campaign, and the number of rockets fired at Israel from Gaza topped 3,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Is Just as Confused About the New Mask Guidelines as You Are
description: In the opening sketch of “Saturday Night Live,” Kate McKinnon played Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, attempting to explain the latest recommendations for people who are fully vaccinated.
content: If you still have questions about the newest recommendations for fully vaccinated Americans issued earlier this week by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, “Saturday Night Live” has answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Fresh Hope at Long Last for Libyans
description: The Biden administration is making the right moves in war-ravaged Libya.
content: The promotion of Richard Norland to be the Biden administration’s special envoy for Libya may seem relatively insignificant when Israel is exploding and the Palestinians are dying and the administration is focusing most of its Middle East bandwidth on Iran and Yemen. But Libya has one distinct leg up on competing crises: Restoring some American credibility, leadership and sobriety could go a long way to stabilize the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Three Views of ‘The Motherboard Suite,’ Indoors, Outdoors and Online
description: Bill T. Jones brings a program of Saul Williams’s work to a New York Live Arts festival of ideas as audiences adjust to the city’s reopening.
content: “Anybody out there know what Afrofuturism is?” Bill T. Jones asked in the middle of Times Square on Saturday night.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In pictures: A wave of violence grips the Middle East.
description: A new round of deadly violence erupted in the Middle East over the past week, as Israeli airstrikes hit targets in Gaza and the militant group Hamas launched rockets at cities inside Israel.
content: A new round of deadly violence erupted in the Middle East over the past week, as Israeli airstrikes hit targets in Gaza and the militant group Hamas launched rockets at cities inside Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Justin Gatlin Is at Home at Tokyo’s Test Event
description: Gatlin was one of nine international athletes invited to participate in a test event in the Olympic Stadium. He came away with a win, and confidence that the Games could go ahead successfully.
content: Last weekend, the American sprinter Justin Gatlin walked to the starting line of a 100-meter race at Olympic Stadium in Tokyo alongside six other sprinters. It was perhaps one of the more ordinary sights the running world had seen in the past year and a half.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Missing Houston Tiger Is Found Unharmed, Police Say
description: The 9-month-old Bengal named India is expected to be taken to a ranch, the Houston police said.
content: A tiger that was last seen wandering around a residential neighborhood in Houston last weekend has been found and “appears to be unharmed,” the Houston police said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Tens of Thousands Evacuated in India Ahead of Cyclone Tauktae
description: The cyclone is expected to make landfall on India’s northwest state of Gujarat on Sunday evening.
content: Tens of thousands of people have been evacuated from their homes in India as a severe cyclone barreled toward landfall on India’s northwest state of Gujarat Sunday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Schools in the U.S. should continue to use masks, C.D.C. advises.
description: The announcement sought to clarify the surprise recommendation that vaccinated people could largely stop wearing masks in most cases.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Saturday clarified coronavirus advice for American schools, recommending the continued, universal use of masks and physical distancing, after the agency’s sudden announcement that vaccinated Americans could forego masks indoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Aaron Judge’s Mastery Over Baltimore Continues in Win
description: Domingo German pitched well in easy victory. The Mets, meanwhile, allowed 15 hits in loss to Rays.
content: BALTIMORE — Aaron Judge homered for the third time in two games, Domingo German had another stellar outing at Camden Yards and the Yankees beat the Baltimore Orioles, 8-2, on Saturday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: For Trump, Hamas and Bibi, It Is Always Jan. 6
description: Netanyahu and Hamas both have a similar understanding of what it takes to remain in power.
content: There are many ways to understand what is happening today between Hamas and Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu of Israel, but I prefer to think about it like this: They are each having their own Jan. 6 moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Where to Order a Blizzard
description: Wren Schultz has a lot to juggle, but downtime happens.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Wren Schultz, who as you are reading this is fulfilling a lifelong dream, brings us a bright puzzle to start the week. And while we are dutifully filling it in, he is taking (a small) part in a movie being filmed. OK, he’s an extra, but that’s extra cool, right? And, he says, the downtime on set gave him a chance to promote this Monday puzzle to his castmates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Katherine Barber, Who Defined Canadian English, Is Dead at 61
description: As the founding editor of the Canadian Oxford Dictionary, she turned to “trashy novels” and parliamentary debates to find Canada’s version of the language.
content: In Canada, it's possible to find a man lounging on a chesterfield in his rented bachelor wearing only his gotchies while fortifying his Molson muscle with a jambuster washed down with slugs from a stubby.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: States Revive Rule Requiring Jobless to Seek Work or Lose Their Benefit
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 16, 2021.
content: “Going out and just casting a wide net and seeing whether a random business will take you is not safe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Kelso and Nailah Morgan
title: Dozens More Killed in Israeli Airstrike as Gaza Violence Escalates
description: An Israeli airstrike in Gaza killed at least 33 people and a separate strike bombed the home of Hamas’s leader. The militant group Hamas also fired rockets into Israel, as conflict continued into Sunday.
content: An Israeli airstrike in Gaza killed at least 33 people and a separate strike bombed the home of Hamas’s leader. The militant group Hamas also fired rockets into Israel, as conflict continued into Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Help Stressed-Out Teenagers
description: Readers offer advice for parents, students and schools, such as modifying expectations, taking a gap year and de-emphasizing grades.

title: Bitcoin’s Effect on Global Warming
